Breast cancer can have different symptoms for different people. Many don't notice any signs at all.
The most common symptom is a new lump in your breast or armpit that doesn't go away.
bullets: Texture changes to the skin on your breast, such as a rash, redness, or dimpling. The skin could resemble the peel of an orange.
Swelling in your armpit or near your collarbone. This could mean breast cancer has spread to lymph nodes (small organs that are part of your immune system) in that area.
Pain and tenderness, although lumps don't usually hurt. Some may cause a prickly feeling.
A flat or indented area on your breast. This could happen because of a tumor you can't see or feel.
Breast changes such as a difference in the size, shape, texture, or temperature of your breast.
Changes in your nipple, like one that: Pulls inward Is dimpled Burns Itches Develops sores
Unusual nipple discharge. It could be clear, bloody, or another color.
A marble-like area under your skin that feels different from any other part of either breast.

Breast cancer can have different symptoms for different people. Many don't notice any signs at all.
The most common symptom is a new lump in your breast or armpit that doesn't go away.

Pain and tenderness, although lumps don't usually hurt. Some may cause a prickly feeling.

sections.heading: Early Signs of Breast Cancer
content: Many people don't have any symptoms at first. And different types of breast cancer may cause different symptoms. But some common early signs of breast cancer include:
A lump is often the first symptom of breast cancer . A hard lump with irregular edges is more likely to be cancer. But some cancers are soft and have rounded edges.
Often, a lump is too small for you or your doctor to feel. That's why it's important to get regular mammograms if you're over 40 or have a family history of breast cancer.
Keep in mind that most breast lumps aren't cancerous. More commonly, lumps are caused by:
bullets: Cysts, which are collections of fluid that are usually harmless
Fibroadenomas , which usually happen before menopause and may be caused by hormones that regulate your period. They don't require treatment and could shrink over time.
Fibrocystic breasts , which is when your breasts are naturally lumpy. They may be lumpier and more painful right before your period.
Breast infections. Small sacs of pus (abscesses) often happen after childbirth.
Clogged milk glands
Injuries that form scar tissue

A lump is often the first symptom of breast cancer . A hard lump with irregular edges is more likely to be cancer. But some cancers are soft and have rounded edges.
Often, a lump is too small for you or your doctor to feel. That's why it's important to get regular mammograms if you're over 40 or have a family history of breast cancer.
Keep in mind that most breast lumps aren't cancerous. More commonly, lumps are caused by:
bullets: Cysts, which are collections of fluid that are usually harmless

content: Always see your doctor if you notice a new lump on your breast. Find out more on causes and types of breast lumps.
Sometimes, people notice swelling before they feel or see a lump. So it's also important to see your doctor if it happens to you. You might have:

Most breast pain isn't caused by cancer. But pain, tenderness, or burning in the breast or nipple could be the first sign of inflammatory breast cancer or Paget's disease, which are among the rarer types of breast cancer. See your doctor if your breast pain is serious or lasts a long time.
bullets: A thickening in part of your breast
Swollen lymph nodes under your arm or near your collarbone

Swollen lymph nodes under your arm or near your collarbone

But pain, tenderness, or burning in the breast or nipple could be the first sign of inflammatory breast cancer or Paget's disease, which are among the rarer types of breast cancer. See your doctor if your breast pain is serious or lasts a long time.

sections.heading: Ductal Carcinoma Symptoms
content: Ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer. It begins in your milk ducts. About 1 in 5 new breast cancers are ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). This means you have cancer in the cells that line your ducts, but it hasn't spread into nearby tissue.

content_blocks.text: Ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer. It begins in your milk ducts. About 1 in 5 new breast cancers are ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). This means you have cancer in the cells that line your ducts, but it hasn't spread into nearby tissue.

content: Most of the time, DCIS doesn't cause any symptoms. More than 90% of cases are found by an imaging test. But you could have:
But ductal carcinoma can also be invasive, which means it spreads beyond the ducts.
bullets: A lump
Discharge from your nipple
Itching in the breast area

content_blocks.text: Most of the time, DCIS doesn't cause any symptoms. More than 90% of cases are found by an imaging test. But you could have:
associated_bullets: A lump
Discharge from your nipple
Itching in the breast area

content_blocks.text: But ductal carcinoma can also be invasive, which means it spreads beyond the ducts.

sections.heading: Invasive Breast Cancer Symptoms
content: Any type of breast cancer that's spread from where it began into the tissues around it is called invasive or infiltrating. You may notice:
bullets: A lump in your breast or armpit. You might not be able to move it separately from your skin or move it at all.
One breast that looks different from the other
A rash or skin that's thick, red, or dimpled like an orange
Skin sores
Swelling in your breast
Small, hard lymph nodes that may be stuck together or stuck to your skin
Pain in one spot

content_blocks.text: Any type of breast cancer that's spread from where it began into the tissues around it is called invasive or infiltrating. You may notice:
associated_bullets: A lump in your breast or armpit. You might not be able to move it separately from your skin or move it at all.

Small, hard lymph nodes that may be stuck together or stuck to your skin
Pain in one spot

sections.heading: Lobular Carcinoma Symptoms
content: Lobular carcinoma begins in the glands that make milk, called lobules. It's the second most common type of breast cancer. Symptoms include:
bullets: Fullness, thickening, or swelling in one area
Nipples that are flat or point inward (inverted)

sections.heading: Metastatic Breast Cancer Symptoms
content: Without treatment, breast cancer can spread to other parts of your body, including other organs. This is called metastatic , advanced, or secondary breast cancer. Depending on where it is, you may have:
bullets: Bone pain
Headache
Changes in brain function
Trouble breathing
Belly swelling
Yellow skin or eyes (jaundice)
Double vision
Nausea
Loss of appetite and weight loss
Muscle weakness

content_blocks.text: Without treatment, breast cancer can spread to other parts of your body, including other organs. This is called metastatic , advanced, or secondary breast cancer. Depending on where it is, you may have:
associated_bullets: Bone pain
Headache
Changes in brain function
Trouble breathing
Belly swelling
Yellow skin or eyes (jaundice)
Double vision
Nausea
Loss of appetite and weight loss
Muscle weakness

sections.heading: Triple-Negative Breast Cancer Symptoms
content: Breast cancer is called triple-negative if it doesn't have receptors for the hormones estrogen and progesterone and doesn't make a lot of a protein called HER2. This kind tends to grow and spread faster than other types, and doctors treat it differently.
Triple-negative tumors make up 10% to 15% of breast cancers. They cause the same symptoms as other common types, such as:
Get an overview on triple-negative breast cancer symptoms and treatment.
bullets: A lump or swelling
Pain in your breast or nipple
Skin that's dimpled, dry, red, or thickened
Discharge
Nipples that turn inward

content_blocks.text: Breast cancer is called triple-negative if it doesn't have receptors for the hormones estrogen and progesterone and doesn't make a lot of a protein called HER2. This kind tends to grow and spread faster than other types, and doctors treat it differently.

Nipples that turn inward

sections.heading: Male Breast Cancer Symptoms
content: About 1% of breast cancers happen in men. Some of the symptoms are similar to the signs of breast cancer in women. But because it's so rare, you may not pay attention to the symptoms until the cancer has grown.
Learn more about breast cancer in men .
bullets: A lump or thick spot in your breast or armpit
Changes in the skin of your breast or nipple, such as redness, puckering, scales, or discharge

content_blocks.text: About 1% of breast cancers happen in men. Some of the symptoms are similar to the signs of breast cancer in women. But because it's so rare, you may not pay attention to the symptoms until the cancer has grown.

associated_bullets: A lump or thick spot in your breast or armpit
Changes in the skin of your breast or nipple, such as redness, puckering, scales, or discharge

content_blocks.text: Learn more about breast cancer in men .

sections.heading: Symptoms of Pagetâs Disease of the Breast
content: Paget's disease often happens along with ductal carcinoma. It affects the skin of your nipple and areola. Symptoms may look like eczema and include:
Read more on the causes and symptoms of Paget's disease .
bullets: Nipple skin that's crusted, scaly, and red
Bloody or yellow discharge from your nipple
A flat or inverted nipple
Burning or itching

content_blocks.text: Paget's disease often happens along with ductal carcinoma. It affects the skin of your nipple and areola. Symptoms may look like eczema and include:
associated_bullets: Nipple skin that's crusted, scaly, and red
Bloody or yellow discharge from your nipple
A flat or inverted nipple
Burning or itching

content_blocks.text: Read more on the causes and symptoms of Paget's disease .

sections.heading: Inflammatory Breast Cancer Symptoms
content: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare type that causes symptoms similar to an infection. They include:
bullets: A breast that's warm, swollen, and red
Skin that's dimpled, leathery, or ridged
A nipple that turns inward
Unusual nipple discharge

content_blocks.text: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare type that causes symptoms similar to an infection. They include:
associated_bullets: A breast that's warm, swollen, and red
Skin that's dimpled, leathery, or ridged
A nipple that turns inward
Unusual nipple discharge

sections.heading: Papillary Carcinoma Symptoms
content: Papillary carcinoma is a very rare type of ductal cancer. It's named for the tiny lumps, or papules, on the tumor. Common symptoms include:
bullets: A small, hard cyst
Bloody discharge from the nipple

content_blocks.text: Papillary carcinoma is a very rare type of ductal cancer. It's named for the tiny lumps, or papules, on the tumor. Common symptoms include:
associated_bullets: A small, hard cyst
Bloody discharge from the nipple

sections.heading: Angiosarcoma Symptoms
content: Fewer than 2% of breast cancers are angiosarcoma s . These start in the cells that line your blood vessels or lymph nodes. Angiosarcoma may cause:
bullets: A lump in your breast
A purple area of skin that looks like a bruise
Skin that bleeds easily when scratched or bumped
Pain in one area

content_blocks.text: Fewer than 2% of breast cancers are angiosarcoma s . These start in the cells that line your blood vessels or lymph nodes. Angiosarcoma may cause:
associated_bullets: A lump in your breast
A purple area of skin that looks like a bruise
Skin that bleeds easily when scratched or bumped
Pain in one area

sections.heading: Breast Cancer Recurrence Symptoms
content: Breast cancer can come back, or recur, long after treatment. It may be in the same breast (local), in the lymph nodes near the original cancer (regional), or in a part of your body that's farther away (metastatic or distant).
Cancer is most likely to come back in the first 2 years after treatment. After that period, the risk goes down over time.
Your doctor will talk with you about what to watch for. Local symptoms include:
bullets: A new lump in your breast
Changes in your breast, nipple, or skin
Lumps on the skin of your chest
Thickening on or near the scar from surgery to remove a breast ( mastectomy )

content_blocks.text: Breast cancer can come back, or recur, long after treatment. It may be in the same breast (local), in the lymph nodes near the original cancer (regional), or in a part of your body that's farther away (metastatic or distant).
Cancer is most likely to come back in the first 2 years after treatment. After that period, the risk goes down over time.
Your doctor will talk with you about what to watch for. Local symptoms include:
associated_bullets: A new lump in your breast
Changes in your breast, nipple, or skin
Lumps on the skin of your chest
Thickening on or near the scar from surgery to remove a breast ( mastectomy )

content: Mastectomy and surgery to replace a breast (reconstruction) may lead to a buildup of scar tissue or fat cells. These lumps aren't cancer. But it's important to let your doctor know about them and watch for changes.
Symptoms of metastatic recurrence depend on what body part is affected. The most common places are your bones, lungs, brain, and liver. You may have:
Know more about what to expect when breast cancer comes back.

bullets: A lump or swelling under your arm, above your collarbone, or on your chest
Swelling in your arm
Pain or numbness in your arm or shoulder
Constant pain in your chest
Trouble swallowing
Bone pain
Dry cough
Loss of appetite and weight loss
Severe headaches
Trouble seeing
Seizures
Balance problems
Confusion

content_blocks.text: Mastectomy and surgery to replace a breast (reconstruction) may lead to a buildup of scar tissue or fat cells. These lumps aren't cancer. But it's important to let your doctor know about them and watch for changes.

associated_bullets: A lump or swelling under your arm, above your collarbone, or on your chest

Constant pain in your chest
Trouble swallowing

content_blocks.text: Symptoms of metastatic recurrence depend on what body part is affected. The most common places are your bones, lungs, brain, and liver. You may have:
associated_bullets: Bone pain
Dry cough
Loss of appetite and weight loss
Severe headaches
Trouble seeing
Seizures
Balance problems
Confusion

content_blocks.text: Know more about what to expect when breast cancer comes back.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Breast cancer symptoms vary from person to person, and many people don't have any symptoms in the early stages. Some common symptoms include breast lumps, pain, swelling, and changes to the skin. If you notice any unusual changes to your breasts, see a doctor.

content_blocks.text: Breast cancer symptoms vary from person to person, and many people don't have any symptoms in the early stages. Some common symptoms include breast lumps, pain, swelling, and changes to the skin. If you notice any unusual changes to your breasts, see a doctor.

sections.heading: Papillary Carcinoma Symptoms
content: Papillary carcinoma is a very rare type of ductal cancer. It's named for the tiny lumps, or papules, on the tumor. Common symptoms include:
bullets: A small, hard cyst
Bloody discharge from the nipple

content_blocks.text: Papillary carcinoma is a very rare type of ductal cancer. It's named for the tiny lumps, or papules, on the tumor. Common symptoms include:
associated_bullets: A small, hard cyst
Bloody discharge from the nipple

sections.heading: Angiosarcoma Symptoms
content: Fewer than 2% of breast cancers are angiosarcoma s . These start in the cells that line your blood vessels or lymph nodes. Angiosarcoma may cause:
bullets: A lump in your breast
A purple area of skin that looks like a bruise
Skin that bleeds easily when scratched or bumped
Pain in one area

content_blocks.text: Fewer than 2% of breast cancers are angiosarcoma s . These start in the cells that line your blood vessels or lymph nodes. Angiosarcoma may cause:
associated_bullets: A lump in your breast
A purple area of skin that looks like a bruise
Skin that bleeds easily when scratched or bumped
Pain in one area

sections.heading: Breast Cancer Recurrence Symptoms
content: Breast cancer can come back, or recur, long after treatment. It may be in the same breast (local), in the lymph nodes near the original cancer (regional), or in a part of your body that's farther away (metastatic or distant).
Cancer is most likely to come back in the first 2 years after treatment. After that period, the risk goes down over time.
Your doctor will talk with you about what to watch for. Local symptoms include:
bullets: A new lump in your breast
Changes in your breast, nipple, or skin
Lumps on the skin of your chest
Thickening on or near the scar from surgery to remove a breast ( mastectomy )

content_blocks.text: Breast cancer can come back, or recur, long after treatment. It may be in the same breast (local), in the lymph nodes near the original cancer (regional), or in a part of your body that's farther away (metastatic or distant).
Cancer is most likely to come back in the first 2 years after treatment. After that period, the risk goes down over time.
Your doctor will talk with you about what to watch for. Local symptoms include:
associated_bullets: A new lump in your breast
Changes in your breast, nipple, or skin
Lumps on the skin of your chest
Thickening on or near the scar from surgery to remove a breast ( mastectomy )

content: Mastectomy and surgery to replace a breast (reconstruction) may lead to a buildup of scar tissue or fat cells. These lumps aren't cancer. But it's important to let your doctor know about them and watch for changes.
Symptoms of metastatic recurrence depend on what body part is affected. The most common places are your bones, lungs, brain, and liver. You may have:

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Breast cancer symptoms vary from person to person, and many people don't have any symptoms in the early stages. Some common symptoms include breast lumps, pain, swelling, and changes to the skin. If you notice any unusual changes to your breasts, see a doctor.

content_blocks.text: Breast cancer symptoms vary from person to person, and many people don't have any symptoms in the early stages. Some common symptoms include breast lumps, pain, swelling, and changes to the skin. If you notice any unusual changes to your breasts, see a doctor.

sections.heading: Breast Cancer Symptoms FAQs
content: How long can you have cancer without knowing?

It's possible to have breast cancer for years before symptoms begin. And many common breast cancer symptoms, like lumps and pain, can also be caused by other things. It's a good idea to be familiar with how your breasts look and feel so you'll notice any changes.
What are the silent signs of breast cancer?
Most people are aware that a lump on the breast can be a sign of breast cancer. But research has shown that many don't realize these are also breast cancer symptoms:
bullets: Discharge from the nipples
Puckering, dimpling, or thickening of the skin on the breast
Nipples that lie flat or point inward or downward
Loss of feeling in areas of the breast

meta_description: Breast cancer is most easily treated if spotted early. Learn the signs and symptoms of breast cancer and talk to your doctor immediately if you experience any of these signs.
